ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
knowledge - critical look @ the historical archive, nuances of black voices
skills - improvement of critical thinking skills, writing skills
insights - history is not linear
Understanding and appreciating historical fiction, reading critically, understanding and appreciating different art forms

My writing skills really grew in this class and I have learned to write about Black archives and analyzing unorthodox forms of Black literature that often times place Black people in an unimaginable realm.

I learned a lot about Black literature, but specifically literature outside of the classics. This class is wonderful because the narratives we read and works we analyze connect to Blackness on a very personal level.
Learned how to look at historical fictions and extract the meaning and context from it to garner a better image of dated events.
Looking at historical fiction beyond the white cannon

This course helped me to study intent in literature and how it impacts and relates to outcome, especially and namely in black text. Such a perspective expanded my understanding of the nature of literary experiment, why writers use it. The emphasis on black themes also challenged the idea of a curriculum or a canon, forcing us as a class to consider the questions themselves but also what these questions meant for us, given our positionality and place.

I learned a lot about the structure of the Black archive. I learned that the Black archive is largely written by white men via slave ledgers. In order to combat the depictions of the Black individuals through these accounts, Black academics engage in critical fabulation, which provides a counternarrative to the degradation of the black race by white people

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths - classroom comfortability, engagement, textual connectivity 
weaknesses - I would often leave class unsatisfied by the extent to which texts/subject matter was discussed (this may have just been a time constraint issue) maybe assign low stakes a few focus questions for a couple students to prepare for and lead w/ during the next class
Strengths: strong reading materials, great instructor, wonderful discussions
I think the teacher should continue the course as is! She does an amazing job and i dont have much critic.
This course was very well organized, and our class discussions were really good

The biggest strength of the course is the syllabus. Having page numbers helps with pacing yourself, content warnings help protect yourself, etc. A weakness is that the content can be (generally) very traumatic as we were reading slave narratives and slave owners journals and other texts that discuss the dehumanization of Black people. I found that aspect of the course draining at times and wish we spent more time on healing or temperature checks rather than viewing the texts with such objectivity.
I wish there were more graded mini assignments that could give me practice writing. Hadn't written in around a year when the course started and felt like I needed to catch up.

Strength: good mix of types of and mediums of materials we studied 

Weaknesses: took discussion sections a while to reach a truly engaging level

While reading-heavy, the size of most of the readings and structure of the course meant that it felt like all of the texts got sure, thorough discussions, and all of the readings themselves were unique and fascinating. The class was clearly organized, with a detailed syllabus. The course gears itself toward discussion, often freewheeling, covering the broad range made available by the writings, taking intense, novel turns.
For those who are new to Black history, the books that are read can be slightly convoluted and hard to follow. However, the shorter material read and discussed is extremely interesting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! the interdisciplinary approach is appealing. We touched on literature and history as expected but also other forms of media like visual/performance art, film, and biology.
Absolutely. One of my favorite classes I've taken here so far.
Yes! This course teachers Black history in a way Ive never learned nor analyzed before.
Yes, I would

Yes. The workload is a bit heavier than your average seminar (& I think definitely it should count for a writing credit) but the readings are well-paced and engaging. Discussion quality, of course, rides on who is in the class.
Yes! Its so important to learn through a Black lens and especially for Black students to learn through their identity and to have their understandings of history made academic

I would certainly recommend this course to another student. Bringing the perspective of counternarrative into black fiction charges the readings in a particular way. The texts for this class were fascinating and thoroughly studied, leading to lengthy, intense discussions between students and the professor.
